Chapter 3: Maitreya, from the chapter on the eyes of the sky in the MahÄsaá¹ƒnipÄta SÅ«tra, the third chapter on Maitreya. At that time, Maitreya Bodhisattva, in front of the Buddha, contemplated and spoke a verse, asking the TathÄgata:

The Buddha said:

The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, turns the wheel of the Dharma in the absence of the path in order to destroy the three kinds of paths of sentient beings.
What are the three paths?
First, the path of afflictions;

third, the path of karma.
The path of karma refers to the activities and existence;
The path of afflictions refers to ignorance, craving, and grasping;
The path of suffering refers to consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, sensation, birth, old age, and death, etc.
How do these three paths come to be?
They exist due to the condition of contact.
Good man!

Because of seeing forms with the eyes, a mind of attachment arises. The mind of attachment is ignorance. Creating karma out of attachment is called formation. Single-mindedly focusing the mind is called consciousness. Consciousness together with form and activity is called name-and-form. The six sense bases giving rise to craving is called the six sense bases. Seeking to experience through the sense bases is called contact. The mind of attachment is called craving. Seeking these dharmas is called grasping. The arising of such dharmas is called becoming. The uninterrupted succession is called birth. The successive cessation is called death. The suffering of birth and death is called distress. Up to the dharmas of consciousness, the causes of craving are also like this.
Thus, the twelve links of dependent arising are all complete in a single person's single thought.
There are three kinds of emergence:
First, causal emergence;
Second, initial emergence;
Third, path emergence.
If there is a bhiká¹£u who cultivates the practice of the Dharma and observes the characteristics of the mind of attachment,
Bhiká¹£us should contemplate: if there is a mind of craving, it is precisely ignorance. The essence of ignorance can give rise to two faults:

Consciousness also has two aspects:
First, it gives rise to name;
Second, it gives rise to form.
Name and form also have two aspects:
First, it is without abiding;
Second, it abides in the six sense bases.
The six sense bases also have two aspects:
First, it is not disgusted with desire;

Contact also has two aspects:
First, it gives rise to the mind of feeling;
Second, it seeks feeling.
Feeling also has two aspects:

Craving also has two aspects:
First, it firmly binds;
Second, it seeks grasping.
Grasping also has two aspects:
First, it is a greedy mind;
Second, it seeks existence.
Existence also has two aspects:
First, it delights in abiding;
Second, it gives rise to the causes and conditions of birth.
Birth also has two aspects:
The first is birth and aging;

Aging also has two aspects:
The first is the decay of youthful appearance;

If there are those who wish to attain the fruit of pratyekabuddhahood, they should contemplate such twelve links of dependent arising, and then contemplate the causes and conditions of the three feelings:

The winds in this body are also like this. There are winds that can rise, winds that can descend, winds that can fill, winds that can dry up, and winds that can increase. Therefore, the inhalation and exhalation of the breath are called bodily actions;
Because inhalation and exhalation arise from contemplation, they are called mental activity;

Because of grasping, one receives a later body, so it is called becoming.

Therefore, by contemplating the in-and-out breath, one can give rise to all suffering and afflictions. Therefore, when ordinary beings are born, they are also bound by afflictions, and the same is so at death;
